title: Adding annotate_ray() callback for plots

content.raw:
It's best to avoid bare excepts, since it makes debugging very difficult and can lead to strange behavior.

Do you know what exceptions you're catching here and below?
content.html:
It's best to avoid bare excepts, since it makes debugging very difficult and can lead to strange behavior.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

I think there's probably a much nicer way to get at this information than three nested try/except blocks. What I would recommend is moving each conditional into other functions, and using either hasattr or using a construction like

type_name = getattr(self.ray, "_type_name", None)
if type_name == "ortho_ray":
    start_coord, end_coord = self._process_ortho_ray()
elif type_name == "ray":
    start_coord, end_coord = self._process_ray()
elif hasattr(self.ray, "light_ray_solution"):
    start_coord, end_coord = self._process_light_ray()
else:
    raise ...

content.raw: I don't think these are used
content.html: I don't think these are used

content.raw:
You can probably save a lot of text by using this construction:

```
#!python
xax = self.ray.ds.coordinates.x_axis[self.ray.axis]
yax = self.ray.ds.coordinates.y_axis[self.ray.axis]
```
content.html:
You can probably save a lot of text by using this construction:

yax = self.ray.ds.coordinates.y_axis[self.ray.axis]

content.raw:
Hmm, could we do:

```
#!python

start_coord = self.ray.ds.domain_left_edge.copy()
start_coord = self.ray.ds.domain_right_edge.copy()
```

and then just fill in the x/y axes?
content.html:
Hmm, could we do:

start_coord = self.ray.ds.domain_left_edge.copy()
start_coord = self.ray.ds.domain_right_edge.copy()

and then just fill in the x/y axes?

content.raw: Also, it makes me sad about how the ray object works that the correct way to back out start/stop is with these inverse axes lookups.  :(
content.html: Also, it makes me sad about how the ray object works that the correct way to back out start/stop is with these inverse axes lookups. :(

content.raw: I had considered using an if isinstance(ray, orthoray) elif isinstance(ray, LightRay)... setup, but advice online suggests that if...then loops with isinstance aren't as pythonic as using try...except pairs.
content.html: I had considered using an if isinstance(ray, orthoray) elif isinstance(ray, LightRay)... setup, but advice online suggests that if...then loops with isinstance aren't as pythonic as using try...except pairs.

content.raw:
A web programmer said that :wink: 

I think nested try, except clauses like this are harder to reason about.

content.html: Oh, I didn't notice that. I am not a fan of isinstance; I thought the getattrs were better. Well, whatever, this is probably fine.

description:
This adds the ability to overplot a line representing a `YTRayBase`, `YTOrthoRayBase`, or `LightRay` object on a `PlotWindow` plot.  It correctly deals with rays traversing a periodic volume.  For the `LightRay` object, it identifies the appropriate section of the `LightRay` that matches the volume being plotted, and it only overplots that part.  I've included docstrings, docs, and tests for this callback.

For a demonstration of this callback in action, see:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/anonymous/8cf2c666adec0fee7e1a

UPDATE1: Added specificity to try/except catches.

UPDATE2: Cleaned up the try..except pairs to be isinstance if...then statements.  Also cleaned up the reverse index lookups for ortho_ray thanks to suggestions by @MatthewTurk .

UPDATE3: Added check to make sure underlying dataset was periodic before allowing periodic rays to be overplot.

UPDATE4: Broke up into sub-functions and removed isinstance() calls.  Fixed bug which would crash callback when no intersecting LightRay segments were found with the current plot.
